pros.7: The benefits are good. Some of the people that I worked with were pretty decent they followed the mission well. I believe they have good intentions at OSF.
pros.8: Level 1 trauma center that will allow you to see a lot and help you gain knowledge
pros.10:
Decent pay 
Option to work remotely
pros.11: Good experience as a new RN. Tuition paid for.
pros.12: This company offers flexibility, which is wonderful.
pros.13: working at the hospital while going to nursing school was great for me to get experience in and only work one 12 hour shift a week to be considered part-time
pros.14: Good job security with great people to work with.
pros.15: Team environment, lots of exposure to healthcare industry.
pros.16: Schedule is very flexible. Supervisor is accommodating. Great if you have school aged children
pros.17: Cool people to work with, and good experience.
pros.19: Great management, Great employees, Amazing job at training and making sure you are confident to start.
pros.21: Everyone is kind and very helpful. When I think of the word "team" I think of OSF
pros.22: Treats their employees as valued members of the healthcare team
pros.24: Plenty of opportunities that are available.
pros.25: The unit I was on we were all family and acted as such.
pros.26: Great People and lots of overtime
pros.27: You might get a pointcore umbrella as your holiday bonus

pros.49: Pay is fair for the role

cons.1: Not enough doctors to keep up with patient demand.   Nurses are overworked. You have  to use PTO time for Holidays.  No overtime available.  Annual raise is not enough to keep up with the cost of living.
cons.2: On-Call coverage at night during weekdays and weekends. Career growth is difficult to achieve. High turn over with new employees due to call responsibilities.
cons.5: Understaffed, unsafe Patient Ratios, 12 and a half hour shifts with only a 30 minute break, and lack of support from management on the floor
cons.7: Management is terrible. If someone doesn't like you they are able to bully you and there are no repercussions. I have never worked in a department that was so awful and toxic in ALL of my life. I would never recommend, to a friend, a position in Sterile Processing Department!
cons.8: Lots of patients to see, heavy workload
cons.11: Benefits aren�t great. Not much room for moving up.
cons.12: A feeling of disconnection between systems and departments.
cons.13: the specific manager I had was not the best
cons.14: Non for profit so pay and benefits are at the lowest in the profession.
cons.19: They will fire an employee very quickly
cons.20: Lots of overtime, 40plus hour work weeks
cons.21: Benefits are not great. Not a lot of growth opportunity unless you want to take on more work without any pay. Leaders do not help you reach your professional goals. You get told one thing and then the leaders go against it. You barely see your manager/direct report because they are in charge of multiple departments and in soooo many meetings.
cons.22: pay is less than surrounding organizations
cons.25: It all depends on what you think are cons
cons.26: Have to use vacation time for holidays
cons.27:
They will steal your PTO for holidays 
They will retroactively charge you for a simple urgent care visit at one of their facilities because their employee healthcare will deny to cover the cost
Benefits in general are atrocious

cons.30: Hours, pay, working holidays, and working weekends.
cons.31: Long hours, flexibility not always accommodated
cons.32:
Without being raised as a new graduate at this facility the staff nurses treat newcomers like they don�t know anything. There is a rigid adherence to how the nursing body has always done things as opposed to best practice or the companies own current policies. Leadership prefers testaments of long running staff members to discern their best moves. Human Resources for employee relations is not an asset, they strongly side with leadership and are generally unreachable. This network leads to cliques running the unit, as they can report and expect responses to planned cohesive statements whether their singling out of a staff member is warranted, truthful, or not.
- very low hourly pay for the state
cons.33: Pay, Pay, pay, benefits, and Pay
cons.35: Work-life balance is non existent and every where is understaffed
cons.37: can't express any cons at this moment
cons.38: the case management department is unfair to social workers and favors RNs. they do the exact same job but RNs make more and SWs need more education. leadership is terrible and they have a hard time keeping case managers for more than a year.
cons.39: Lots of overtime, 40plus hour work weeks
cons.42: Busy place and can get hectic
cons.43: sometimes forced to work at multiple facilities - schedule can be confusing
cons.46: Lack of management presence and short staffed
